if we take the outer length, that is, d(theta).(r + dr) , then  dA = d(theta). (r + dr) * (dr)         = r.dr.d(theta) + r.dr^2.d(theta) the last term contains a square of dr, which is much smaller than dr when dr is very small itself. Hence the last term is very dispensable.  so the first term, r.dr.d(theta) prevails.

The moment of inertia about the origin is given by the doble integral over R of (r^2)*delta*dA where delta is the mass density of R and dA is the infinitesimal area element (see 38:25). In this example, R is formed by all the "points" inside the circle of radius a. Then, the limits of integration that "sweep" all those points are (0, a) for r, and (0, 2*pi) for theta. The mass density delta is constant and it is equal to 1 (see 43:29). The infinitesimal area element dA is given by r*dr*dtheta by the explanation in 6:50. Hence, the integrand is (r^2)*r*dr*dtheta after replacing dA and delta in the expression for the moment of inertia.

+Jay Son never a stupid question if you're trying to learn. usually a unit circle has the right angle along the x-axis. Since we're using the hypotenuse as the x-axis, everything needs to be moved around.  I hope this explains it a little :)

You can get the same answer in a different way . The equation of circle with center (a,0) is (x-a)²+y²=a². Now expand the equation you will get r²-2ax=0. Now substitute x=rcos(theta) . So the final equation becomes r=2acos(theta).

At most top universities like MIT, students from middle and lower-income families pay little to no tuition. The ones that do pay close to full tuition come from higher-income families.   From the article MIT announces increase to undergraduate financial aid for 2022–23 academic year  1) The estimated average MIT scholarship for students receiving financial aid next year is $59,916.  2) Last year, more than 37 percent of MIT undergraduates received aid sufficient to allow them to attend the Institute tuition-free.  3) The 2022-23 undergraduate financial aid program will include enhancements to make MIT tuition-free for families who have typical assets and whose incomes are below $140,000 (previously set at $90,000), as well as additional financial aid dollars that will reduce the amount paid by most families  4) even families earning more than $250,000 may qualify for financial aid based on their circumstances, such as if two or more children are in college at the same time  5) In 2021, 82 percent of MIT seniors graduated with no debt; of those who did assume debt to finance their education, the median indebtedness at graduation was $15,721  It doesn't get much more fair than that.

@aVerKePedo So the thing that's happening here is that he's not finding the area of a circle, he's finding the volume of a region above a surface that 'looks' like a circle. What he plots there is the base of the surface, which is where you get your bounds of integration from.  If he was finding the area of a circle, the double integral of r*dr*dø with those bounds would indeed be correct and would yield pi/4 because the formula for the circle would be sqrt(x^2+y^2) = r = 1.
